g.text: Int. J. Environ. Res. Public Health
The author contributions to this manuscript are as follows: conceptualization, M.Mand
O.A.O.; methodology, M.M. and S.H.; interviews, M.M.; transcription, M.M.; formal analysis, M.M. and S.H.;
writing—original draft preparation, M.M. and S.H.; writing—review and editing, O.A.O.; supervision, O.A.O.;
project administration, O.A.O.; funding acquisition, M.M.
Financial support for this research was provided by the University of California, Irvine, Graduate
Division, Water UCI, and the Data Science Initiative.
No support given which is not covered by the authors’ contribution or funding sections.
The authors declare no conﬂicts of interest.
1. Moser, S. Communicating Climate Change Adaptation and Resilience.
2. Burton, I. Vulnerability and Adaptive Response in the Context of Climate and Climate Change.
3. Frumkin, H.; McMichael, A. Climate Change and Public Health: Thinking, Communicating, Acting.

Washington, DC, USA; Roundtable on Population Health Improvement: Washington, DC, USA; Board
on Population Health and Public Health Practice: Washington, DC, USA; Institute of Medicine: Bational

, 5th ed.; Battelle Press: Columbus, OH, USA, 2013.
6. Levine, A.; Kline, R. A new approach for evaluating climate change communication.
, B. Risk Perception and Communication Unplugged: Twenty Years of Process.

Forcing People to be Green or Fostering Grass-Roots Engagement?

14. Kasperson, R. Four questions for risk communication.

and their inﬂuence on relationships with place.
